heading: International FEES coming in July for MP.  I'm unclear of some things.
body: @gwzcompsÂ wrote:I understand that, but do they pay with US currency? Not something I have tracked TBHThe way that it currently works right now with Pay Pal is that you the seller pay a 1.5% cross border trading fee on your end for every international transaction. Â The buyer pays an additional 2.5% on PayPal's daily currency conversion spread to convert their foreign currency into US Dollars. So you the seller only ever see a transaction that was paid in US Dollars, and you incur the additional 1.5% "cross border trading fee" applied to the transaction. So every seller ends up paying 4.4% (2.9% + 1.5%) + $0.30 on one of these types of transactions.Â The way that eBay's terms of service for Managed Payments read now it appears that eBay is asking the seller to pay 1.65% for a cross border trading fee and an additional 3% currency conversion fee to now be paid for by the seller instead of the buyer. Making the total extra cost to be incurred by the seller an additional 4.65% on top of the category FVF base rate. Or maybe they are charging both the seller as well as the buyers on both ends to convert that buyers native currency into US Dollars. Who know at this point as eBay, the eBay Payments Team, and Mr. @brian_burke@ebay have been silent for the past two weeks about the particular details concerning how international transactions will be handled now through eBay's New Managed Payments.Â And like @mam98031 I to would like to now how EXACTLY this will work so that I can make plans accordingly between now and July 20, 2020.Â So far @siamjane8 has called eBay Managed Payments customer service 3 times last week and had it confirmed that eBay will be charging a 4.65% additional fee for all international transactions, but I for one would like to here that from an eBay employee here on the Payments board in writing. I am not sure that CS reps can always be trusted and relied upon to pass on factual knowledge regarding the details and nuances of how international transaction have been traditionally processed through eBay and then comparing that to how they will now be processed through Managed Payments. I can easily see were this could be lost on an eBay CS rep, even if their specialty is Managed Payments. Â @siamjane8 's post regarding eBay CS's confirmation that 4.65% is what seller's can expect to be charged in the future for international transactions through Managed Payments, on a different Managed Payments tread discussion from last week. Post #466https://community.ebay.com/t5/Payments/Managed-Payments-Answers-to-some-Frequently-Asked-Questions/t...

heading: Ebay will refund taxes in case of a return?
body:
@original_otisÂ wrote:
I'm going through this as well, and when I googled this is the first thread I saw.Â  Lots of bad information here.Â  The ONLY way eBay refunds automatically is if it's a FULL REFUND.Â  If you order multiple items and only some have been returned/refunded, eBay does NOTHING and just keeps the taxes.
Â 
After e-mailing and messaging multiple times I was finally told that the request would be submitted and take 72 hours.Â  It's been six weeks for me and I haven't received the refund for taxes on over $1,600.Â  I'm not actually sure how it can be legal for eBay to not automatically and immediately refund and instead just wait to see if people notice they're not getting their money back.
Â 
Also to clarify.Â  THIS ALL WENT DIRECTLY THROUGH EBAY.Â  I requested the return, shipped, and got all notifications for return/refund through eBay.Â  They even told me at first that all my taxes were refunded (because they didn't do the math, just decided that the seller must have also refunded taxes even though they didn't collect taxes).

HiÂ @original_otis,Â any refund issued through eBay (either Full or Partial) will also trigger an automatic refund of the tax paid for that portion of the transaction; for example, if 50% of the original payment is refunded, 50% of the taxes are refunded. For refunds issued through eBay, the seller is not able to affect the amount of tax refunded as this is calculated and processed in conjunction with the refund issued. If for some reason this does not happen automatically, we can ensure this is processed manually. If the seller refunds their buyer directly through PayPal, they would need to calculate and include the appropriate tax amount themselves. While the seller does not directly collect these taxes, the taxes are processed through the transaction and their account, so any refunds directly on PayPal do require the seller to take into account the tax portion that needs to be refunded as well. After the refund is issued through the transaction in PayPal, the tax amount would be credited to them. If their calculation was incorrect and a buyer is still missing a portion of their refund, eBay could address this to ensure the buyer is fully refunded.Â 

	Trinton,Community Team

heading: Ebay will refund taxes in case of a return?
body:
@original_otisÂ wrote:
Hi Trinton,
Â 
It appears to me that it all went through eBay since I received all notifications of return and refund through eBay but I definitely did not receive a refund for the taxes.Â  No matter what though, I have sent messages to eBay and was told that I'd see the refund payment within 72 hours but I have not.Â  I have $1,600+ in returns that I have not received a tax refund for.Â  I'm not sure what the process is for getting me the money back, but I shouldn't have to be so hands on with it.Â  eBay and Paypal are connected.Â  When I'm refunded eBay says "You got your refund" why aren't they also saying "And here is the refund for taxes that we took"?Â  At this point, I'm past all of that and have sent a message showing EVERY item that was refunded, what the purchase/refund total was, and what I'm owed in total for the taxes and I haven't gotten a resolution.Â  So what else am I supposed to do?Â  eBay has this money, and it should be sent to me.

HiÂ @original_otis,Â while most refunds (including the tax paid) process without an issue, sometimes eBay has to be notified of an issue so we can step in. There are a number of reasons why this may occur, and though we've worked to minimize these situations, it is an unfortunate side effect of payments being processed by a third party. While we partner with PayPal, we are not able to directly control the payment and refund process. Many of these issues should be resolved as we move more and more sellers into the managed payments program, and in the meantime we can manually address any issues that come up.I know you've contacted us already so can recommend that you either follow up to one of the previous emails you received or contact us using the options found at the bottom of the related help page (here).

	Trinton,Community Team

heading: ebay refund when item in transit
body: @paradiso*bella*a*venireÂ wrote:I would email the buyer and say " I see your item finally arrived. When may I expect repayment for this item"Â I would say report the buyer, but because the item remained MIA for such a long period of time,(which is the key element here) Â and because ebays system, by design, is set up for this type situation to end in favor of buyer, I dont really see anything thats reportable.Â Â Â Things are more complicated because it is an international sale.Â  They have already tried to contact the buyer and the buyer isn't responding.Â  There isn't a lot left to do as a seller except move on.Â  Frustrating to be sure, but not much of anything that can be done about it.

heading: ebay refund when item in transit
body: If you shipped via USPS priority mail, I am not sure why you didn't file an online insurance claim for lost package with USPS a long time ago. Priority mail comes with free insurance. I believe it is a free $200 for priority international and you can file as soon as 7 days after shipment. Now that it shows delivered, you won't be able to file a claim.Â Â And it is not that eBay doesn't care, it's just not eBay's responsibility to refund you. I understand this scenario is frustrating, but lost/delayed packages are legally the responsibility of the seller. It is out of the seller's control most of the time, but it is still the seller's responsibility. Shipping insurance protects sellers from loss or damage. If you want to protect yourself in the future, shipping insurance is the way to go. You have to put yourself in the buyer's shoes - 80+ days is an extremely long time to wait for a package. I don't think the buyer should keep it for free without talking to you, but I personally (as a seller) wouldn't expect a buyer to re-pay (at least not full price) for such a long delivery time.Â Â If I were you, I would start insuring all of my packages (US and international, no matter the class) through a third party shipping insurance. I use Shipsurance, but there are other companies. It's cheap and easy to file a claim. Lost/delayed packages are at a much higher occurrence right now than ever before, so even if you don't do it long term it is wise to do right now.

heading: Has Those In Managed Payments Experienced Increase to Category FVF?
body: brian_burke@ebayÂ wrote:Â @mcdougle4248Â wrote:@nuclearomenÂ wrote:I got email last week that I need to register for Managed Payments by July 15th. In which lead me to start looking into the help pages on Managed Payments. I talked to two CS Reps and got two different answers. According to help page here:Â https://www.ebay.com/help/selling/selling-fees/store-fees?id=4809Â  FVF's for store tiers Basic and up all the FVF's are more then without Managed Payments. In example, my main category Music > Records is currently 9.15% + Paypal 2.9 % + 0.30 but according to the chart Managed Payments FVF on same category is 11.5% + 0.30 which is indeed an FVF increase yet it seems if this correct that they are taking paypal away and raising FVF's to pretty match what is taken out without Managed Payments and payment through Paypal - saving you...0.05%??? Since can't get straight answer (ever) from Ebay CS can anyone in managed payments currently confirm this?Â Â Keep in mind when doing your calculations that the MP fees starting in July will be calculated using the total sale price including the item price, shipping charge and sales tax.Â Â @nuclearomenÂ Â @mcdougle4248Â 9.15%+2.9% = 12.05%. The new fee will be 11.5%. That is a 0.55% savings over 1/2 a point, not a 0.05% savings as you state.Â Most sellers registering now will see a savings. Look at your overall fees, sometimes a buyer will not pay tax (no tax state or they have a reseller license). And Top rated plus will be applied to everything (except the $0.30).Â I hope this clarifies.Â Â BrianBrian - I just wanted to ask that you please be careful in what you are stating. I understand that you are simply repeating the Ebay announcement but that has been proven to be specifically misleading. By charging the FVF on the sales tax- nearly ALL transactions will result in a fee INCREASE under managed payments.Â  You admitted to this on the Payments discussion board so for you to later and knowingly continue to tell sellers on this board that the % FVF is will result in cheaper fees is misleading and could be considered lying on behalf of the company.Â  The cat is out of the bag and ebay needs to decide if it wants to move forward with a fee hike in a pandemic or not.Â  If this was for simplicity - the fee structure could have been a 5% across the board FVF. That is simple. Of course I realize that is not doable for financial reasons - just an example why Ebay should call a spade a spadeÂ  - if they want to make more profit at the direct expense of my profit....... just say it and own the decision but please do not try to fool, mislead, and trick your sole customer base. WE ARE NOT IDIOTS WE ARE YOUR CUSTOMERS.

heading: Has Those In Managed Payments Experienced Increase to Category FVF?
body: This just proves my theory that eBay like usual is lying to us about making things better while they are ACTUALLY making things worse.Â  We will only save money as sellers if we are selling in the lower fee categories and/or to people in the lower sales tax brackets.Â  This system is being rushed into place forcing some people to not be able to sell what they currently sell.Â  Also we don't get access to OUR money as fast like with PayPal.Â In the end you can make the argument that the difference isn't much.Â  Us sellers aren't on eBay's payroll though so we have to make every penny count.Â  Also if anyone at eBay wants to make that argument then I would challenge them to cover that difference out of their own pocket.Â  Rather than ramrodding this down our throats as supposedly being better, just be honest and call it what it is.

heading: Has Those In Managed Payments Experienced Increase to Category FVF?
body: brian_burke@ebayÂ wrote:Â @mcdougle4248Â wrote:@nuclearomenÂ wrote:I got email last week that I need to register for Managed Payments by July 15th. In which lead me to start looking into the help pages on Managed Payments. I talked to two CS Reps and got two different answers. According to help page here:Â https://www.ebay.com/help/selling/selling-fees/store-fees?id=4809Â  FVF's for store tiers Basic and up all the FVF's are more then without Managed Payments. In example, my main category Music > Records is currently 9.15% + Paypal 2.9 % + 0.30 but according to the chart Managed Payments FVF on same category is 11.5% + 0.30 which is indeed an FVF increase yet it seems if this correct that they are taking paypal away and raising FVF's to pretty match what is taken out without Managed Payments and payment through Paypal - saving you...0.05%??? Since can't get straight answer (ever) from Ebay CS can anyone in managed payments currently confirm this?Â Â Keep in mind when doing your calculations that the MP fees starting in July will be calculated using the total sale price including the item price, shipping charge and sales tax.Â Â @nuclearomenÂ Â @mcdougle4248Â 9.15%+2.9% = 12.05%. The new fee will be 11.5%. That is a 0.55% savings over 1/2 a point, not a 0.05% savings as you state.Â Most sellers registering now will see a savings. Look at your overall fees, sometimes a buyer will not pay tax (no tax state or they have a reseller license). And Top rated plus will be applied to everything (except the $0.30).Â I hope this clarifies.Â Â Brian".....sometimes a buyer will not pay tax......"Â Great so now sellers will have only a 78% chance that Managed Payments will cost them more due to sales tax remittance.Â eBay collects sales tax for 39 states and the District Of Columbia for a total of 40 out of 51 possible.Â And how long until the 6 out of 11 remaining states that have a sales tax adopt a Marketplace Facilitator law that do not currently have a law on the books right now.Â In the next couple of years the only states that eBay sellers will not be paying a FVF on sales tax collected will be for the 5 states do not charge a sales tax.Â Â And then what will a seller's chances be?46 out of 51.Â But of course you guys have already this out haven't you?

heading: Has Those In Managed Payments Experienced Increase to Category FVF?
body: @mcdougle4248Â wrote:brian_burke@ebayÂ wrote:Â @mcdougle4248Â wrote:@nuclearomenÂ wrote:I got email last week that I need to register for Managed Payments by July 15th. In which lead me to start looking into the help pages on Managed Payments. I talked to two CS Reps and got two different answers. According to help page here:Â https://www.ebay.com/help/selling/selling-fees/store-fees?id=4809Â  FVF's for store tiers Basic and up all the FVF's are more then without Managed Payments. In example, my main category Music > Records is currently 9.15% + Paypal 2.9 % + 0.30 but according to the chart Managed Payments FVF on same category is 11.5% + 0.30 which is indeed an FVF increase yet it seems if this correct that they are taking paypal away and raising FVF's to pretty match what is taken out without Managed Payments and payment through Paypal - saving you...0.05%??? Since can't get straight answer (ever) from Ebay CS can anyone in managed payments currently confirm this?Â Â Keep in mind when doing your calculations that the MP fees starting in July will be calculated using the total sale price including the item price, shipping charge and sales tax.Â Â @mcdougle4248Â 9.15%+2.9% = 12.05%. The new fee will be 11.5%. That is a 0.5% savings 1/2 a point, not a 0.05% savings as you state.Â Most sellers registering now will see a savings. Look at your overall fees, sometimes a buyer will not pay tax (no tax state or they have a reseller license). And Top rated plus will be applied to everything (except the $0.30).Â I hope this clarifies.Â Â BrianI agree with you in that sellers should look at the overall fees they are paying now and compare those to the new fee structure beginning in July.Â  Â Â I agree with this as well.Â  We do need to look at this as on overall effect.Â  If most of our transactions have sales tax on them then it is likely we will be paying a little more in fees.Â  If it is a good mixture of non taxable sales and taxable sales then we have a better chance of it running neutral or possibly a little cheaper.Â It is important however to keep in mind for all of us that the majority of states do have a sales tax.Â  I set up an Excel worksheet and I'm tracking and comparing fees on MP vs what is currently being charged on Ebay w/ PP.Â  I'm doing this for May and June to get at least an idea of what this Simplified Fee is really going to mean to me in the future.Â  So far in May it is pretty neutral but I've had quite a few non sales tax sales.Â  Time will tell what the facts will be for what I might be experiencing.Â I am however still very unclear as to the impact of the new fees on International sales.Â  That part is pretty muddy to me right now.Â Â Â brian_burke@ebay

heading: Has Those In Managed Payments Experienced Increase to Category FVF?
body: @go-bad-chickenÂ wrote:".....sometimes a buyer will not pay tax......"Â Great so now sellers will have only a 78% chance that Managed Payments will cost them more due to sales tax remittance.Â eBay collects sales tax for 39 states and the District Of Columbia for a total of 40 out of 51 possible.Â And how long until the 6 out of 11 remaining states that have a sales tax adopt a Marketplace Facilitator law that do not currently have a law on the books right now.Â In the next couple of years the only states that eBay sellers will not be paying a FVF on sales tax collected will be for the 5 states do not charge a sales tax.Â Â And then what will a seller's chances be?46 out of 51.Â But of course you guys have already this out haven't you?no one from ebay of course has answered me. But i said this myself, and it's also impossible to predict what state a sale will come from to even know how much sales tax will be charged until after order is placed. Ebay wants to press the idea of a "streamlined one charge process" and forward the idea that they are saving you money doing it this way, but it isn't nor is it for the sellers convenience it's specifically constructed to and for the purpose to save Ebay money by charging all on only one transaction they then pay less to the processing company allowing them to pocket more profit. Plus charging fee on sale tax Ebay will pocket millions more a year on that alone. This is all designed for Ebay to be able to make growth profit, just as promoted listings was/is. Ebays future profits lay in fees as they can't make it any other way, yet they can make profit and actually more by lowering FVF's and providing a more incentive to sellers to stay on the platform rather then leave or attract new sellers, they are just unwilling to. You can see this is many examples of the coming changes, with FVF for non-store subscribers starting at 12.35% clearly showing ebay want to force all sellers, no matter what size to have a store subscription yet at same time clearly giving those with store subscriptions next to no real discount (1-2% depending on tier) but recouping that "savings" by charging fees on shipping and tax. Next, push is to have as many sellers as possible quality for TRP listings and give the 10% discount (where you'll ultimately only going to see savings in managed payments).Â I'm still not certain of how fees will be compiled to sellers offering free shipping like myself. I may start charging for shipping when managed payments starts if they are going to charge me on it and adjust shipping charge by $2 since I ship a lot of media mail and if I need insurance I have to pay for that cost since ebay doesn't have an option for buyers to add it unlike priority option where $100 insurance is automatically added.

heading: Has Those In Managed Payments Experienced Increase to Category FVF?
body: But consider not all sales have sales tax.Â  So for those sales your fees are likely to be lower in MP than they are currently.Â  It is the mixture of the two kinds of sales [with and without] that may just work out to be a neutral affect [no rate increase].Â  We have to look at it overall, not for a single transaction.Â I'm running a personal test for myself.Â  I built a worksheet in Excel and I will track my sales for May and June, compare the MP rates with the current rates in Ebay w/ PP.Â  That should give me a better idea if this is really an increase, decrease or net neutral.Â I encourage others to do the same thing so you can gain a better understanding of how this impacts you.Â  We have a mixture of sales, so it won't be the same for everyone.

body: @nuclearomenÂ wrote:@go-bad-chickenÂ wrote:".....sometimes a buyer will not pay tax......"Â Great so now sellers will have only a 78% chance that Managed Payments will cost them more due to sales tax remittance.Â eBay collects sales tax for 39 states and the District Of Columbia for a total of 40 out of 51 possible.Â And how long until the 6 out of 11 remaining states that have a sales tax adopt a Marketplace Facilitator law that do not currently have a law on the books right now.Â In the next couple of years the only states that eBay sellers will not be paying a FVF on sales tax collected will be for the 5 states do not charge a sales tax.Â Â And then what will a seller's chances be?46 out of 51.Â But of course you guys have already this out haven't you?no one from ebay of course has answered me. But i said this myself, and it's also impossible to predict what state a sale will come from to even know how much sales tax will be charged until after order is placed. Ebay wants to press the idea of a "streamlined one charge process" and forward the idea that they are saving you money doing it this way, but it isn't nor is it for the sellers convenience it's specifically constructed to and for the purpose to save Ebay money by charging all on only one transaction they then pay less to the processing company allowing them to pocket more profit. Plus charging fee on sale tax Ebay will pocket millions more a year on that alone. This is all designed for Ebay to be able to make growth profit, just as promoted listings was/is. Ebays future profits lay in fees as they can't make it any other way, yet they can make profit and actually more by lowering FVF's and providing a more incentive to sellers to stay on the platform rather then leave or attract new sellers, they are just unwilling to. You can see this is many examples of the coming changes, with FVF for non-store subscribers starting at 12.35% clearly showing ebay want to force all sellers, no matter what size to have a store subscription yet at same time clearly giving those with store subscriptions next to no real discount (1-2% depending on tier) but recouping that "savings" by charging fees on shipping and tax. Next, push is to have as many sellers as possible quality for TRP listings and give the 10% discount (where you'll ultimately only going to see savings in managed payments).Â I'm still not certain of how fees will be compiled to sellers offering free shipping like myself. I may start charging for shipping when managed payments starts if they are going to charge me on it and adjust shipping charge by $2 since I ship a lot of media mail and if I need insurance I have to pay for that cost since ebay doesn't have an option for buyers to add it unlike priority option where $100 insurance is automatically added.Â I have a couple of seperate businesses here on eBay and elsewhere on the internet.Â But one of those businesses is a book buisness. So eBay new Simplified Fee wants me to pay 14.35% on the sales tax, shipping, and the cost of the item.Â But I'm not going to buy into brian_burke@ebay or eBay's narrative that sometimes I will save some money and sometimes I won't based on the buyer's location.Â My real question and what every other seller who is here question should be is why can eBay process sales tax at say 3.8% for some sellers and other sellers at 6.9%, and yet I the book seller get left holding the bag at 14.35%.Â See brian_burke@ebay can come out here to community and give this program a good shine on for the company. And for a few sellers it will cost less, for most sellers it will cost a good deal more, but for media sellers.... forget about trying to hide that stink. Because are no two ways about it. Managed will absolutely cost media sellers more money.Â Â But I have figured out how to not pay any FVFs at all. Sell sneakers for a $1000.Â In what other world other than eBay does that seller get to pay $0.00 in sales tax fees and I the book sellers get to pay $14.35. That is just crazy.Â This really needs to be a flat percentage rate of 2.5% to 5% on sales tax collected otherwise this begins to look like a serious deal killer for me, when I consider the other advantages that I am already giving up, in conjunction with this fee hike.Â I may have to start doxing all of the sneaker sellers for not carrying their fair share of the water.

heading: Excessive CAPTCHA Issues
body: If anyone still has this issue,. this worked right away for me.Â  Right click on your eBay link and select properties.Â  In the location line delete what is there and then copy and past this below:https://signin.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dllÂ Click save,Â  then go to the link and right click again, check properties and the location, if the location is what you pasted above and it saved correctly, you should now be able to use that link to connect without a captcha.Â Â 'rgards

heading: File Exchange BAF.Error.4 Unparseable Line

heading: So... a buyer REALLY has 35 days to return an item (not 21) and Ebay scripted "customer service"
body: Previously, buyers had 5 business days to get tracking started on a return. With the update, buyers were given 10 business days if the seller provided an eBay-issued return label, or 35 business days if the seller uploads their own label.Â In the former, buyers now have a pandemic-extended 21 business days to get tracking started, and sellers have 5 business days, up from 2 business days, to refund after the return is delivered back.Â Sellers can no longer ask eBay to close a return, and eBay still waits 5Â  business days beyond the buyer's deadline before automatically closing a return.Â Changes to handling return requests that appear abandonedStarting April 1, 2020, we will no longer close returns early at the request of a seller when the buyer has not shipped the item back. Instead, we will wait to ensure buyers have sufficient time to provide proof items they requested to return were shipped back. If we do not receive proof of shipment from your buyers while the return requests are active, we will protect you by removing any negative or neutral feedback left on that transaction.

heading: So... a buyer REALLY has 35 days to return an item (not 21) and Ebay scripted "customer service"
body: I can see the panic in the spur of the moment decisions Ebay made... one problem is that I just don't have the time to read all the seller updates thoroughly.Â Â My BIG problem is the repetitive scripted customer service reps.Â I was a customer service rep for big corporations in the 1980's and 1990's.Â  We had to KNOW what we were talking about and educate the customer as a PERSON. Not a machine. If we had to credit a customer for something at our expense to make them happy, we did it.Â I think if the rep took the time to LISTEN and educate me as to the above referenced policy, I might have been a little happier. It's not up to other users on these boards to do Ebay's job of customer service. It's kind of like going to the store and using self checkout (no offense bebe-1153... you did a good job of explaining).Â I still don't know why Ebay extended this return policy. I mean, we are all supposed to be HOME... RIGHT?!?!? Ã°Å¸â„¢â€š At least in April we were.Â I just have to wait it out.

heading: So... a buyer REALLY has 35 days to return an item (not 21) and Ebay scripted "customer service"
body: No, actually, not ALL of us are supposed to be at home.Â  I know this because I have a granddaughter who is an RN in a local hospital on the unit where the Covid-19 patients are receiving care.Â  Due to the concurrent closing of all local schools and some businesses, she has accepted extra 12 hour shifts to cover for some of her co-workers who are unable to come to work because of home schooling children, or having toddlers in day care facilities which are closed also.Â  I know other folks locally who are working, some more than usual.And, if you don't have time to read the seller announcements or updates, then it seems you'll just have to accept the consequences of that lack of information.Finally, maybe you were unaware of this, but all CS reps are working from home and are short staffed.

heading: Why I am being overcharged by 30c - 50c on each purchase when using my Ebay gift card?
body: @baypopper66Â Â What is your state's sales tax rate? Â 8.25% ?Â Does your state charge sales tax on shipping?Many states do.Â To maintain the same ratio ....For the 3 examples provided by you, the sales tax amount quoted would have to be calculated based on the selling price only.Â Now, if you apply that same implied tax rate to the shipping cost, you arrive at the 3 differences you noted.

heading: So... a buyer REALLY has 35 days to return an item (not 21) and Ebay scripted "customer service"
body: So, I have been mulling over your reply and I want to say first I appreciate the sacrifices your granddaughter is making.Â  I have a niece who is a nurse and also friends in the healthcare industry and they are working pretty hard... at least where there are major effects of the pandemic.Â I guess my two main complaints are buried in my rant.Â  Sooo...Â The extending of the return time for buyers. I get it. If you are quarantined for 14 days, you can't get out of the house. I guess I'm one of the few "old timers" left on Ebay that believes in communicating with the other party about a transaction.Â  If Ebay left things alone... if a buyer got an item and was dissatisfied, let's work it out. If you want to return it, that's fine. In this case it was a pair of jeans that the buyer probably didn't read the listing description about too well. They opened a return the day they got them and said they were too small. No worries. I approved the return.Â If they contacted me up to and including the day they were supposed to upload tracking and say "Hey, I can't get these out to you today... (for whatever reason), but can get them out next Thursday", I would reply "No problem, just update tracking once they are in the mail". Ebay has taken that away from me. I have reached out to the buyer and have heard absolutely nothing. But I will wait. No big deal.Â The other thing is the level of customer service these Ebay reps have. Whether they are short staffed and working from home, or in their office, the reps I always seem to get are so scripted and afterwards, I wonder why I waste my time calling.Â  If they are working from home right now, it doesn't really matter. That should be transparent to me as the caller. For the last few years their lack of training, parroting what I say and canned responses have irritated me.Â As far as seller updates, they come pretty quickly. Today, I got two of them... yesterday I got one. Plus Ebay messages about watched items ending, items I looked at once ending, the "Sorry you missed out on this item " messages, etc. I scan these messages when I get them, but there's so much to try to remember. My feeling is that's (again) what a company's customer service is for. If you have questions on some new policy of the month you missed, they can educate you on it in a professional manner.

heading: Why I am being overcharged by 30c - 50c on each purchase when using my Ebay gift card?
body: I appreciate your response but am not quite following ... on each of these occasions I am the purchaser, the items come from various US locations and I thought I was already paying tax on my purchases as noted, which I assumed varied depending which state I was buying from.Â That said, you may have a point here as I am in TX and yes our sales tax is 8.25 ... so do I pay tax twice ... once to the selling state and once to my own?

heading: So... a buyer REALLY has 35 days to return an item (not 21) and Ebay scripted "customer service"
body: I'll share your rant. I completely agree that this extended time period to ship an item after a return is initiated is ridiculous.Â  35 business days is 7 weeks.Â  Really, 7 weeks to get an item in the mail?!Â Â I had a return (due to fit) that was opened on 3/25 with no acceptance scan, no communication or further tracking information.Â  I emailed a request to have it closed by customer service.Â  The first customer service rep replied that unfortunately they were unable to help me and it would be automatically closed after 35 business days.Â  Apparently if no tracking is uploaded, the buyer gets 35 days to return it/ upload tracking because eBay assumes that they are taking it to the post office to mail (not printing eBay provided postage).Â  Only after I pointed out it is 5/15 and already several days past the 35 days was I able to get the return closed by a second rep.Â  Unfortunately, he didn't simply close the return, but had to open a case and decide it in my favor.Â  I always feel concerned that an opened case (although found in my favor) could have a negative effect on my selling metrics, so not very happy about that result.Â Â Â I would like to know why the return did not automatically close as promised?Â  This happens frequently that a buyer will start a return and then change their mind, but leave the abandoned return open.Â  It takes forever to time out and the only thing sellers can do is call or email customer service to get it closed.Â  A simple "request to close" tab should be available to sellers once the required time to ship has elapsed --better yet, automatically close the return when it has expired!

heading: So... a buyer REALLY has 35 days to return an item (not 21) and Ebay scripted "customer service"
body: @reclaimed_denimÂ wrote:I had a return (due to fit) that was opened on 3/25 with no acceptance scan, no communication or further tracking information. I emailed a request to have it closed by customer service.Â Â The first customer service rep replied that unfortunately they were unable to help me and it would be automatically closed after 35 business days.Â Only after I pointed out it is 5/15 and already several days past the 35 days was I able to get the return closed by a second rep. Unfortunately, he didn't simply close the return, but had to open a case and decide it in my favor.Â I would like to know why the return did not automatically close as promised?It seems you jumped the gun.Â From Wednesday, March 25, 2020 + 35 daysExcluding Weekends and public holidaysResult: Monday, May 18, 2020Â And a return request is between buyer an seller only; by definition, it is a work-it-out and eBay is not permitted to interfere. The only way eBay can take action is to close the request (which you'll notice has an ID number) and open a case (which you'll notice has a new ID number, so it's not the same case). And opening a case, even to just close it, has consequences.Â Also, while you were able to get the return closed early with an escalation on yourself, sellers actually can no longer ask eBay to close a return early, see here.Â Changes to handling return requests that appear abandonedStarting April 1, 2020, we will no longer close returns early at the request of a seller when the buyer has not shipped the item back.

heading: Post office not delivering packages from China????
body: Over the years I've made many purchases from China and other countries and have had good experience overall. Â  Currently, I've got 2 purchases that have not been delivered. Â One was purchased on March 13th.Â  Today, that is 2 months ago.Â  Tracking shows that it was picked up from the Seller and the Seller says it's in USA but there are no updates to the status and I've not received it.Â  In 13 days, I will contact Ebay for a refund but I really wanted the item and I just think that the item is sitting somewhere and is not being delivered. Â Â The second package was shipped by a company called Buylogic - also from China.Â  Looking at tracking, it never went through customs either leaving China or upon entering the USA.Â  The tracking says that "item has been received at the destination Post Office" - that was 5 days ago.Â  I spoke to my local Post Office and they said that they didn't have it and couldn't track that tracking number from their internal system.Â  I was able to track it on the Buylogic website and it just says that the item is received at the destination Post Office.Â Does that mean the final destination or is it received in the USA???? Â  Again, it skipped the step of Customs both leaving China and entering the USA - according to the tracking - so I thought it was airmail of some sort. Â I just sent the Seller a message and asked them if they can tell me where the package is. Â Â I won't be purchasing anything else from overseas until this epidemic is over.

heading: Post office not delivering packages from China????
body:
@orange-spice,Â Â  "One was purchased on March 13th. Today, that is 2 months ago. Tracking shows that it was picked up from the Seller and the Seller says it's in USA but there are no updates to the status and I've not received it. In 13 days, I will contact Ebay for a refund".Â If the tracking information does not show it has arrived in the U.S. then the seller is lying, if they have info saying that they should have sent you the tracking number saying that.Â  If the last estimated delivery date has passed file the item not received dispute now, if ebay wants you to wait fine do what they tell you to do. Â Â  "The second package was shipped by a company called Buylogic - also from China. Looking at tracking, it never went through customs either leaving China or upon entering the USA. The tracking says that "item has been received at the destination Post Office" - that was 5 days ago".Â If this was a Covid related item, the destination post office may be the USPS Customs depot and it was confiscated by Customs.Â  They have started doing that because of the defective and downright dangerous Covid related items being sent from China.Â Â  You will have to wait until the last estimated delivery date. to file an item not received dispute. Buylogic tracking usually has 2 parts, shipping from China, then a USPS tracking number activated when they receive a package.Â Â  "Over the years I've made many purchases from China and other countries and have had good experience overall".Â That means you've had some not so good transactions.Â  Chinese sellers as a group are the most problematic ones on eBay.Â  They regularly use tactics designed to cause buyers to lose their money and/or give up their buyer protections.Â  Since the pandemic out break, the number of complaints about them has increased exponentially.Â  They've been listing items when there was virtually no shipping to and from China.Â  Item location misrepresentation has become a huge problem with them.Â  There has been a huge increase of wrong address showing delivery tracking. Now they are listing items they know will be confiscated.Â Â Â Â  My advice, stop buying from them, and if you must check feedback profiles and click on the numbers of both neutral and negative feedback they've received to read only those comments.Â  Never go by feedback percentages alone. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

	THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS FOOLPROOF, BECAUSE FOOLS ARE SO DARNED INGENIOUS! (unknown)

heading: Post office not delivering packages from China????
body: The BuyLogic tracking doesn't say that it's in customs.Â  It says it's at the destination Post Office. Â I messaged the Seller yesterday and he messaged back that he'd sent it by HK Post and that there was no tracking on it .... in other words, he didn't even look at the listing to see that he shipped via Buylogic.Â  And, my message specifically said Buylogic tracking, too. Â  Tracking number shows "The consignment has arrived in the country of destination" and thenÂ "received by the destination post office"Â Destination post office WHERE????

heading: Post office not delivering packages from China????
body:
@orange-spice,Â Â "The BuyLogic tracking doesn't say that it's in customs. It says it's at the destination Post Office ...Â  Destination post office WHERE?"Â Destination P.O. may mean country of destination postal facility, which can also be a customs receiving center.Â  Usually HK Post tracking stops once a package leaves Chinese control.Â  Have you gone directly to the buylogic site to track the package?Â  You can look that up online, and you might want to do a search of their tracking status terms.Â  The tracking information eBay displays comes from a 3rd party source Pitney Bowes not directly from shippers. Â Â Â  "... he messaged back that he'd sent it by HK Post and that there was no tracking on it .... in other words, he didn't even look at the listing to see that he shipped via Buylogic".Â The seller may be a dropshipper. The item was not in his possesion, but sold from a warehouse. Or they may have shipped the item to Shen Zen Buylogics main facility who does the international shipping.Â  They may just be trying to bamboozle you.Â Â  All you can do is wait until the last estimated delivery date then file an item not receivedÂ  dispute. Â Â  Â Â 

	THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS FOOLPROOF, BECAUSE FOOLS ARE SO DARNED INGENIOUS! (unknown)

heading: Post office not delivering packages from China????
body:
@orange-spice,Â Â Â Â  "Buylogic website says it's at the destination post office".Â You keep repeating that, but have you tried to find out on the buylogic site what that term means?Â Â  If the facility is a shared Customs/USPS facility, until the item clears customs it will NOT enter the USPS system.Â  There is also the possibility the tracking info you've received was an already used one.Â  The seller doesn't seem sure of what system they used which is highly suspect.

heading: Post office not delivering packages from China????
body: I called the Post Office again about the one that I thought was here 45 days and the person I spoke with today says it's never arrived in the USA. Â  About a month ago, the Seller told me that the package was in our country and to wait a few more days for delivery.Â  Today, after I spoke with the Post Office,Â  I tracked it on China Post and it shows that it was handed over to their airline on March 23 but it never shows that it was shipped or received in the USA.Â  So, I've been waiting for 2 months for something that never left China. Â  I've contacted the Seller again...Â Â The other package that was shipped by BUYLOGIC is the mystery now. Â  On eBay and on the Buylogic website it says it's "received at the destination post office" on May 8th - a week ago.Â  Don't know where the destination post office is because my Post Office says they don't have it.Â Â Maybe I'll see that one someday.

heading: Post office not delivering packages from China????
body:
Okay...Â It doesn't matter what the seller says. YOU don't have the package. You can file an item not received dispute one day after the estimated delivery date.Â  Stop worrying about the tracking. Just file the item not received when you can, and escalate it when the option becomes available.Â From what I read here on the boards, those sellers are notorious for stringing buyers along until their time limit on Ebay expires. Once that happens, you're done as far as Ebay is concerned, and you then have to go to Paypal - and a lot of buyers don't realize that Paypal gives you 180 days from the date of purchase to file a claim. These sellers bank on that.Â Protect yourself first. If the items do happen to arrive, you can always repay your seller.

	You know what they say about advice: The wise don't need it, and fools don't heed it.

heading: Well so much for the great "eBay Fee Deferral Program"
body: If you are approved by March 31, 2020 and have an invoice dated March 31, 2020, 50% of the Covered Fees will be deferred until the April 30, 2020 invoice, and the remainder will be deferred until May 31, 2020 invoice.If you are approved between March 31st and April 15th, and have an invoice dated March 31, 2020, expect to pay your monthly March invoice in full as usual. 50% of your Covered Fees on your April 30, 2020 invoice will be deferred until the May 31, 2020 invoice and 50% deferred until your June 30th invoice.If you submit by April 15th and are approved and have an invoice dated April 15, 2020, 50% of the Covered Fees will be deferred until the May 15, 2020 invoice, and the remainder will be deferred until the June 15, 2020 invoice.If approved, please be aware that you will still receive your regular invoice which will include the Covered Fees by this deferment program, as well as any other fees and charges. The non covered fees and charges will be due within the normal payment time frame, and the payment of the Covered Fees will be based on the schedule above.You should check My eBay or Seller Hub for details about what Payments are due:My eBay -> Account -> Seller AccountSeller Hub -> Account Settings -> Seller AccountPlease refer to the Frequently Asked Questions for the list of covered selling fees.

heading: Buyer requested to cancel already approved return with partial refund agreement
body:
@dolli-clarÂ wrote:Are they missing something or are they just fearful that after the case is closed, that I will not send partial refund because they will not be able to RE-OPEN again?Yeah- it's one of those two reasons and no way to know which unless the buyer provides more info.Â You can't do the partial refund through eBay since currently the only way they let you do that is before the return is approved.Â Do the partial refund through PayPal and make sure it's through the original transaction. If the buyer ultimately returns the item the eBay system can't refund them more than what they originally paid. As long as you refund through the original transaction you're good to go. Then the return case will eventually time out if the buyer sends nothing back.

heading: Seller blocked me and I am thoroughly confused
body: You don't.Â  The seller is the final and only judge of who is on his/her Blocked Bidders/Buyers List.Â  Whether he is correct or mistaken about the facts that landed you there it is wholly within his will to put you there or take you off.Â Note that every buyer has a feedback rating of either 100% or 0%.Â  If you got a single feedback in the past 12 months you are 100% because a seller physically cannot leave a negative (or neutral) for a buyer.

heading: Seller blocked me and I am thoroughly confused
body: Well, you don't rectify it, actually. A seller can block anyone for absolutely any reason or no reason at all.Perhaps you can find another seller in order to acquire your item.Good luck!P.S. All buyers have 100% positive feedback--sellers cannot give negative feedback to buyers.Â Sorry,Â @woodland_gnome. Cross posted!

heading: Seller blocked me and I am thoroughly confused
body:
@jld2730,Â Â  "I am an enthusiastic collector and I have a 100% approval rating."Â As a buyer only you will always have a 100% rating, because buyers cannot receive any feedback but positive ones, even the non-payers and scammers. A seller can be sanctioned for leaving a positive with a negative comment, and it can be removed.Â Â Â  "I recently attempted to bid on an item from a legitimate seller who has an extensive collection he is selling. I could not bid because it said I was blocked. I immediately contacted the seller, stating my confusion. He was very snarky in his reply and stated that I bid on something of his and didn't pay within 48 hours. I have gone back over all of my purchases and have never bought anything, nor bid on anything from this seller."Â You may not have any feedback from the seller, because you have not left feedback for any of your sellers.Â  Feedback is voluntary and it does not have to be left by either buyers or sellers, and some sellers will not leave feedback if they do not receive one first.Â  Since buyers can only receive positives, sellers look at feedback they leave to judge their reputation. Sellers on the other hand need to receive feedback to keep a high feedback percentage if they do receive a negative.Â At some point you must have bought from them otherwise they would not know who to block.Â  If you went through your purchase history it may show a transaction if you extend the time frame from [Last 60 days] to 2020 using the drop down arrow.Â Â You can also login to your PayPal account and extend your purchase history back to January 1st. Click on some of the early ones to see the details, which includes seller usernames.Â  Maybe you did make a purchase from them but have forgotten about it.Â If you find you did buy from them. You may want to try contacting them again, apologize saying I may have had an issue at first as a new buyer, but I've straightened it out. Then ask for a second chance.Â  Do not expect a reply however. Many sellers who block buyers also block communication from them. So far that does not seem to be the case.Â  Â Â 

	THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS FOOLPROOF, BECAUSE FOOLS ARE SO DARNED INGENIOUS! (unknown)

heading: Seller blocked me and I am thoroughly confused
body: Ebay is not protecting the seller, the seller is protecting themselves.Â  Could be you asked a redundant question or wanted a lower price or free shipping some other reason than non payment on an auction. Â  The blocked buyer list does not allow for notes with the user ID.Â  The seller may not remember the reason you're blocked and just gave a 'routine' answer.Â Â Ebay is not an open free for all marketplace.Â  They function to facilitate sales between random strangers.Â  Chances are there are plenty of other sellers who will welcome your purchase.

body: This could be a case of mistaken identity: Sometimes when bidders/buyers are blocked they set up a new ID to get around it. So this seller might think that your ID is a new one set up by somebody else that he has dealt with in the past. If you have not actually dealt with him before, then clearly he is mistaken in some way, so you should try not to take it too personally.

heading: Seller blocked me and I am thoroughly confused
body:
It's neither slander or discrimination. Slander well for one would be spoken. Libel written still wouldn't apply since the seller only said these things to you.Â  Libel is when they tell someone else a falsehood about you.Â Â Discrimination is harm caused based on protected classes which doesn't apply either.Â Â Whether the seller is mistaken or not theyhave the right to refuse to do service with you.Â Â

heading: Seller blocked me and I am thoroughly confused
body: Buyers develop amnesia and are surprised to discover they are on a blocked bidder list.I would wager that you have had some interaction with the seller.Â Some behaviors do not leave an audit trail.Using the Make-Best-Offer button and sending an insultingly low offer.Ignoring the fact that the Make-Best-Offer does not appear in the listing and using the message center to send an unwanted best offer anyway.Failure to read the description and asking a question when the obvious answer is in the description.Inquiring about Next Day Air Delivery. Almost 100% of buyers get sticker shock when they find out the price. Then they don't purchase at all. Not even 2nd Day Air or ground.Â Other behaviors leave an audit trail, for a while.You can download 7 years of Paypal history and search the seller's ID for purchases or refunds.Bid retractions.Non paying bidder cases.Cancellation requests.Returning an item, which in reality is buyer's remorse 95% of the time.That causes a loss of Paypal seller fees, postage and unpaid labor to process and relist.

heading: Seller blocked me and I am thoroughly confused
body: The only thing you're out is access to an irate seller. Â Â Â If you're feeling adventurous,Â Â ask seller for specifics. Â What item or transaction was involved? Â When?Â Â If the issue is burning inside your brain, and you're looking for closure.Â Â At this point the good will is burned and you have nothing left to lose.Â Â I would get to the point and keep it brief, limiting the number of questions as well.Â Â Don't want to harass folks on ebay.Â Â Good luck.

heading: Cleaner
body: Because I drive the speed limit and every day these formula one drivers in training zoom past me... They come right up on me and cut in and out of lanes and drive a good 10-20 miles over the speed limit, a lot of times nothing happens... Somehow the police caught me but not them, I did not understand this but when the judge explained to me that one or two more of these incidents they would take my license, why that is when magic happened and I slowed it down.Â So my simple advice to you, don't do it.They will probably catch you and not them.And they will explain to you, one or two more of these incidents and you will lose your selling privileges.You see it is exactly like driving too fast, not a good idea.

heading: Variation Specifics provided does not match with
body: Not all categories are eligible to list with multi-variation. There is a list on ebay that indicates which categories are eligible, but I find that the list is not up to date. You can only be sure if it's eligible by actually trying to list it and then see if the multi-variation option shows up.If you are saying the multi-variation option shows up, but it's not working? Then I suggest you close that listing attempt and start a brand new listing from scratch, not a "sell similar", and see if that works for you.

heading: No longer showing in search
body: @fcfcfc1z1xÂ Â for a brief second the picture of my hat appears but then disappearsÂ If your listing is a sponsored listing, and you are using an ad blocker, the ad blocker is removing the sponsored listing from your search sort after it loads. That is why you can see it initially, and why it disappears -- your ad blocker is blocking it.Â If you use a sort other than "best match", then your listing should appear once as a sponsored listing (which may be blocked) and once as a non-sponsored "organic" listing which sorts normally and should not be blocked.

heading: Buyer doesn't wanna pay sales tax
body: I had a similar one, unfortunately my patience is running short with irate and demanding buyers.Â The only part that gets to me a little is I am starting to think they're inventing things to get what they want.So, had the buyer just asked me to cancel I would've obliged byÂ cancelling for reason of "buyer asked." As things stand however I would now cancel the purchase for reason of "buyer making unreasonable demands."Â Many people may not see the difference in those reasons and it may not matter but it does to me.There is however not much else we can do but yes I would cancel, no reason to entertain trouble further, say a silent thank you for the early warning as it just saved you the shipping costs and what I consider a highly possible trouble filled return.Â LOL. So I didn't even reply to that message of his yet and he sends another reply "I just purchased one on Amazon and did not pay sales tax" No idea what was the point of the buyer telling me that though... as I originally told him the sales tax was controlled by ebay. Amazon obivously doesn't = Ebay.Â Not sure if he's lying. But if he's telling the truth... Hey Ebay! You just lost a precious buyer to Amazon because of your pesky sales tax. So much for trying to be like them.Sounds to me like the buyer is lying. What most likely happened is the buyer found the item cheaper elsewhere but again what can you do, cancel their purchase and get on with life, would've never got to this second message with me.

heading: Is eBay a POS transaction?
body:
Ebay as well Internet purchases are POS."Point of sale (POS), a critical piece of a point of purchase, refers to the place where a customer executes the payment for goods or services and where sales taxes may become payable. It can be in a physical store, where POS terminals and systems are used to process card payments or a virtual sales point such as a computer or mobile electronic device."Â https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/point-of-sale.aspÂ Â

They want to cancel their purchase if they have to pay the tax. How would you deal with that? And how should I respond... looking for message verbiage? Thanks in advance.I didn't charge you sales tax eBay did.Â  I don't have your sales taxes eBay does.Â  If you don't want to pay sales tax I suggest you talk to your local congressman/woman. As they are the ones that set up the laws that told eBay and ALL on-line facilitators to collect those taxes.Â Now if you want to cancel the order that's fine with me, but I do want you to understand that no matter where you buy the items there will be sales taxes paid on them, whether you see it or not.Â Â I'm quite sure there are smarter peeps that will come along and do a much prettier and smarter sounding ones... but it is what I have sent to my buyers.Â  1 shut up and kept the order, another canceled.Take a deep breath and a moment.Â  You will realize this is not a good idea.Â  Simply apologize as Ebay is following their state's law that requires them to collect sales tax, but that you understand and will cancel the transaction and refund them in full ASAP.Â  And then leave it alone.Â  Unless it is your intent to stir up an unneeded and unwarranted conflict.Â Clearly they are new buyers to this site and maybe the internet at large so they just aren't aware of the newer laws.MamÂ  it's the same conceptional response I've sent out since eBay started collecting it.Â  I get 50/50 results... they either hush and decide they want the item anyway... or they pout stomp their feet and go find it elsewhere.Â Again the way I phrased it TODAY was a bit blunter than usual.Â  Usually it has a few I'm sorry's, and it starts a bit nicer... I did tell him to wait till the ones with prettier speech patterns turned up ğŸ˜‰That is a horrible percentage and IMHO not at all worth the risk.Â  There are better approaches IMHO, I certainly wouldn't recommend it.Â  On this thread, we aren't talking about people that have not yet purchased.Â  We are talking about ones that have purchased and paid.Â  That pouting and stomping could easily turn into negative FB.Â I respect why you said it.Â  If I sent my buyers some of the things that run through my mind when they asked question, well let just say I'd probably not be a seller anymore and I would certainly have lots of red donuts on my FB page.Â  I always have to remember to put on my business hat before typing a response.I'm confused.... with my "letter" I have a 50% retention rate vrs a 100% cancel and give me my money back rate (dunno what the technical business words are for the second one).Â When I simply (and nicer than posted here) point out taxes aren't MY fault, and are up to their state congress peeps, half of emÂ go oh.... duh! well never mind about the refund (at least mentally cause NONE of em come back and tell me that part) but will come back and tell me I still want my item, ship it please.Â The other half go, I don't care who's fault it is I'm not paying sales tax give me my money back, and cancel my order.Â  Got it, I cancel they can't leave feedback cause THEY requested a cancel over something I have no control over and if they CAN leave feedback they never have.Â  (hence the pouting and the stomping of the feet as they walk off).Â Â I think the MAIN difference between me and you is though I have worked customer service most of my adult life (and wouldn't pull half my smartical answers working Wal-mart during after Christmas returns)... eBay is my HOBBY I do it for fun, and while I'm never flat out RUDE to the peeps... red donuts don't bother me, neither do the occasional "I don't play ball" defect cause the customer escalated it.Â  (for the record I've not had more than 1 or 2 a year since I started either, and a few of those red donuts I wore with pride LOL).Â If I got kicked off eBay (perma banned from selling) I'd miss the BOARDS more than I'd miss selling... but then again I got that covered ğŸ˜‰

heading: Buyer doesn't wanna pay sales tax
body:
We have mostly cloud cover, darkness and fine drizzle - what I call 'small rain'.Â  I know more than a few people who moved here for a 'gig' and left after about three or so years, stating that anyone who can stand the weather here must be nuts - 10 months out of the year was too much, even with a couple of breaks.Â  Buh-bye.Â  I like it cool, gray and quiet.Â  And believe me, I'm outside a lot, particularly when I worked as a bike courier.Â  I would far rather ride through slop than endure our occasional heat spells when I'd be buried in downtown traffic, hauling up hills like a pack mule huffing in smog, with the sweat running into my eyes.Â  Blech. If it was like that every summer it would be awful.Â Now I have a small gig doing deliveries on my bike again, oddly enough.Â  I'd retired from it in my early 40s and here I am again in my mid-60s, huffing up hills toting stuff... oops.Â  I hope we have a nice, cool summer.Â My DH likes it hot and sunny and complains endlessly about the drizzle - I don't even notice it.Â  We've both lived here almost all of our lives.

No pants, just ashes.

heading: Appealling eBay decision as buyer

I can't reopen it?What do you want to appeal?Â  The return was closed because you didn't ship back the item, but you have $30 ... that is, I believe you have the drive PLUS a refund of $30.Â  There's nothing more that you need to do.Â (I'll admit I'm confused).

heading: Appealling eBay decision as buyer
body:
Im confused..a partial refund means the buyer keeps the item. No seller would give you a refund of any kind first,then expectÂ  you to return the item.If the case is closed, you cant reopen it.Where are you seeing you have to return the item?

``````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````â€œNever pick a fight with an ugly person. They donâ€™t have anything to lose.â€ ~Robin Williams

heading: Appealling eBay decision as buyer
body: You are done with eBay. If you win an appeal, eBay pays, and your seller gets away.Â If you still have the free eBay return label (it doesn't expire) then open a return (SNAD) dispute at PayPal paypal.com/disputes and immediately escalate it to a claim.Â Then when you're asked to return the item, use the return label, and you'll get the full refund when the item is delivered back. If you don't have the return label, then pay for a label with tracking yourself at paypal.com/shipnow; it'll likely cost way less than $30.

heading: Appealling eBay decision as buyer
body: Decision was just made earlier today. There was a link for me to print shipping label to return Hard Drive back to seller. Yes I got partially refunded but I'm suppose to mail it back and lose $30. I want to appeal eBays decision and have seller refund me full purchase of almost $70, then I'll print label and send back the item. How can I appeal if I've already have?

heading: Appealling eBay decision as buyer

heading: Appealling eBay decision as buyer

I can't reopen it?Â You don't have to return the item.Once you accepted the partial refund and was paid, the case was closed.Â If the seller wants the item back, they can pay you the rest and send you a prepaid shipping label.

I'm guessing the seller offered the partial refund you accepted and now the case is closed. And now the seller is asking you to send it back?Â  You do not have to send it back if that's what happened. The seller would the the one who misunderstood what offering a partial refund meantÂ

heading: I've been scammed twice in the past 30 days...
body: Ask the buyer some questions and gauge his/ her responses and response time. You are spending $4K based upon a picture and text. Surely you have a few questions??There is buyer protection on E-bay but it is not fool proof.

heading: I've been scammed twice in the past 30 days...
body:
@rolandwhite99,Â Â Â Â  "The item I want to purchase is a bicycle and the seller hasn't had any activity in his account in over a year. Now all of a sudden, he has two very expensive bicycles for sale."Â What you are describing has all of the signs of a hi-jacked account.Â  If you go back to the seller's profile page and look again I'll bet you find Except for 1 or 2 purchases in the last year or 6 months no activity.Little or No selling feedback. Or if there is some it is not for items related to biking.Â  If you do a search of the photos, you'll probably find they have been used on other sites. The listing probably has an extended delivery time frame over 14 days as well.Because the seller hasn't sold in over a year PayPal will put a 21 day hold on the payment so even if this is a legitimate transaction, there could be problems.Â  "How can I feel safe purchaing from him? Is ebay's guarantee good enough".Â Yes the Guarantee is good enough.Â  However, if the scammer is good / devious enough,Â  getting the refund could take some time, and for that amount you may lose your protections for awhile.Â  If you haven't read the Guarantee's policy andÂ  terms youÂ  could make a mistake, making it harder to get a refund.Â  As others have saidÂ  eBay does not have escrow services.Â  Â Â  You replied to @pburn , "So what is eBay buyer protection good for?"Â Â It is there to protect people who have issues.Â  Though there is a point where a buyer is expected to use their common sense.Â  You've been given some info that should help you make a decision. If a few of the Things I listed are what you are seeing, why risk your time and money.Â  You could miss out on a real deal. Â Â Â 

	THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS FOOLPROOF, BECAUSE FOOLS ARE SO DARNED INGENIOUS! (unknown)

heading: Accidental return open and closed, never received item, seller isnâ€™t getting back to me.
body: Hello. I have an issue with a product that I purchased back on March 23rd. I thought that I would simply try to be patient and wait for the item to arrive due to covid causing shipping limitations. But I received a message from the seller telling me that they received the item back after shipping it due to the outbreak. So we messaged back and forth and were trying to work out a refund, and they seemed helpful. I didnâ€™t know how to get a refund so I was looking through my options and accidentally opened and immediately closed a return without realizing the consequences. I had no idea that in doing that it would resolve the purchase and lock me out of a refund on my end. I messaged the seller right after, itâ€™s been a week now and no response. I donâ€™t want to loseÂ my 115$ if possible. What is the best solution to this? Thanks.

heading: A modification to the charging options for all listings at one time without problems
body: You can try using ebay's bulk editing option.Â Here's my macro for changing handling time.Â  You can use it as a template for whatever change you need to make.Â This is what I did to change handling time to 1-day back when it was required to be a top rated seller:Using Seller Hub, I went to Manage Active Listings.Â  I clicked theÂ  [ ]Â  box in front of Actions to mark all the listings.Â  Then I clicked on the down-arrow next to EDIT and selected Edit all xx listings.Next I clicked theÂ  [ ]Â  box at the top to select all listings.Â  Click on EDIT FIELDS.Â  Click HANDLING TIME.Â  under Edit Handling Time, select CHANGE TO (you can select from 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30 days).Â  SAVE & CLOSE.Â  Click SUBMIT CHANGES.

heading: Would Like Input On Selling Market
body: Hello, I am new to this forum but need some input.Â  I have been an Ebay seller for 20 or more years, took a break, now back selling.Â  I find I am in an entirely new atmosphere from the "good old days" where there were many, many daily sales and you didn't have to lower prices continuously to make a sale and you actually made a profit.Â  Before, I would get up at 3 a.m. to wrap and package sales and have 10 to 15 USPS boxes scheduled for pickup.Â  Now. I don't make that many sales in a week!Â  I am dismayed at the new buyer's market.Â  If items are over $20 they won't buy.Â  This was not a problem before and I still always check active and sold prices on items to price mine accordingly.Â  I have been back a year and this is a constant situation.Â  I can see the virus effecting sales, of course, but our economy was fine until recently but buyers are very tight fisted now.Â  One problem with this is to try and keep shipping on the correct amount as a mistake on shipping will zero out my tiny profit (if there is one).Â  Any thoughts, helpful hints, opinions?

heading: Need help identifying Vintage Army Poster Print?

heading: Need help identifying Vintage Army Poster Print?
body: @argon38Â wrote:Incidentally, Harmon's title is a reference to the 3rd Armored Division (Spearhead) - that's their insignia on the upper right:Â https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3rd_Armored_Division_(United_States)Â Although having said that, the one on his website doesn't actually have the insignia on it:Â http://www.jodyharmon.com/militaryart/leprints.html

heading: Need help identifying Vintage Army Poster Print?
body: @sonomabarn67Â wrote:Not a chance. An extremely faded lithographic print.Looks like that to me, too, definitely.Â And I found that Jody Harmon used this theme -- the old ghostly cavalry and the solid new one, so to speak -- in more than one painting.Â  There's Spearhead, noted by Marguee, but also Eternal Overlook and Armor Strong, to name just two others.Â Â It it were mine, and I decided to pursue it despite the lack of monetary value, I'd compare details, such as how the horse's tack is handled or how the clouds are done, and if they're similar to Harmon's, then carry on searching Harmon's work for this one.

heading: Need help identifying Vintage Army Poster Print?
body: @maxine*jÂ wrote:It it were mine, and I decided to pursue it despite the lack of monetary value, I'd compare details, such as how the horse's tack is handled or how the clouds are done, and if they're similar to Harmon's, then carry on searching Harmon's work for this one.Â Â Â I don't believe this is Harmon's work (it's initialled MR, aside from anything else). I'd say he's familiar with the original of the OP's print and used it as the inspiration for his modern-style version.

heading: Need help identifying Vintage Army Poster Print?

heading: Need help identifying Vintage Army Poster Print?

A tribute.Possible.Â  That's why details need to be compared, to see if it's the same or a different hand.Â  If it appears to be by Harmon, a search will be easy.Â Â If the artists are different, then someone (not me) will have to try ro figure out the date of OP's print and the dates of Harmon's works to see who borrowed from whom.

heading: ebay's putting free shipping on my listings!
body: I recently did a lot of listings, all charging shipping.Turns out ebay shows my listings as having free shipping.I had a buyer make a low-ball offer on an item which I accepted.I then sent an invoice & he was shocked to see $3 shipping was added.I explained that this was a glitch & that we could scratch the transaction.He accused me of adding the shipping, cancelled the order & left me a negative feedback!ebay is not removing the feedback & IT'S EBAY'S FAULT!Â Been selling on here for years. One newbee comes along & puts a bad mark on my feedback score, over something that's out of my control.Ebay sent him a letter of apology saying, "We're sorry you had a bad experience. The buyer sent me a screen shot of it. This letter enforced his viewpoint that I was trying to rip him off.)Meanwhile, ebay has does nothing for me. I lost a sale, I have to re-do all my listings, & I have a negative feedback now.Â Not that anyone cares, but I'm just about done with ebay.

heading: Would Like Input On Selling Market
body: Yep, things have changed in 20 yrs.Â  I, for instance,....... well, let's not go there......Â At one point, you could sell pez dispensers and make a mint......now......not so much.....Â  Ebay once was the only place in town........now......not so much....Â  buyers aren't looking for "fun" as much as what they are specifically looking for.....Collectibles still sell, but so does alot more "stuff" that most of us would never think of buying 20 yrs ago.Â  The basics are still true.......you make the profit when you buy.....but the markets change and those items can end up not worth what you paid for them.Â  So research is the key, selling NOW (my opinion) rather than holding waiting for the markets to go is may be the way to go. Lots of stuff sells for over $20...so I'm not sure why you make that dividing line..... and a number of sellers are doing as well as or better than Xmas sales recently, apparently due to the shut ins....Â  Not every seller, of course.......Â As to your shipping problems (?) not sure what you mean.......if you weigh and measure and use calculated shipping, you should have no problems. Ah..... I see you are using Fedex......which does have its problems according to people on these boards. Â  You might try USPS, if you can, I've never been burned there except a couple of times when I've made an error in inputting the info.........

heading: Would Like Input On Selling Market
body: @scredence2005Â wrote:If items are over $20 they won't buy.Â You've sold over 50 high ends glassware items in the last 40 days alone. Almost every item sold for $20. Maybe your expectations are too high. Also those items have lost demand compared to 20 years ago. Many of the people who bought that stuff have either retired or died. If you can barely make a profit then you will have to accept that fact as when the demand drops so do the prices.

heading: Would Like Input On Selling Market
body:
ETA: This was for the OP.Â I'm like one of those boiled frogs - things happened gradually down through the years so I don't notice too much save that auctions are pretty much a losing proposition and we're at a race to the bottom in some categories (fashion being one).Â  Beyond that - eh - I don't see any wild rides, just some annoyances.Â  Just read the updates and become familiar with any changes - that's very important - getting stuff piecemeal here isn't going to give you a good picture.Â  The returns SNAD procedure sux, though - be certain you're familiar with that.Â The annoying issue coming up is managed payments - but that's something most selling sites have now.

heading: Would Like Input On Selling Market
body: You have to be a lot more creative to make a buck nowadays, all the old tricks people used to use, well everybody knows them even the buyers so they're worn out and done.Â  Best I can tell you is specialize, and become intimate with the products you are selling.You can not just "buy low" and "sell high" anymore, that won't work.You have to actually KNOW your product (and I mean you have used it extensively, not you looked on google and "oh ok I get the idea") it mostly boils down to this, intricate intimate knowledge of what you're dealing in.

heading: Buyer Sent Different Item Back
body: Another thing that seems to have changed is that your reputation means nothing.Â  You could be a 16 year member with 100% feedback on thousands of transactions.Â  But then a new member with 2 feedback responses can come in and wreak havoc with you.Â  That is something that was lost from the beginning of eBay until now.Â  Wasn't that the purpose of feedback?

heading: Buyer Sent Different Item Back
body:
A sellers good reputation and history here means nothing, Ebay will side with the buyer 99.9% of the time in a he said, she said, dispute.

``````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````â€œNever pick a fight with an ugly person. They donâ€™t have anything to lose.â€ ~Robin Williams

heading: Buyer Sent Different Item Back
body: I am reading eBay's policies on its "return items" page.Â  It shows that items worth over $750 must be returned with signature confirmation.Â  We provided a prepaid UPS label with full insurance and signature confirmation to the buyer, but he chose to send it back via USPS with no insurance or signature confirmation.Â  The postage from his location to ours was $14.95.Â  The postal clerk confirmed that there was no additional insurance on it.Â  Plus we calculated it online and saw that full insurance would have been another $17.Â  The UPS label is still active as we decided not to cancel it yet.Â Â I added 3 photos:1) Proof of prepaid UPS label.2) eBay policy showing anything above $750 needs to have signature confirmation.3) Pic of the box that was sent to us with no insurance or signature confirmation.https://www.ebay.com/help/buying/returns-refunds/return-item-refund?id=4041
